questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with symptoms of a respiratory infection. A sputum sample is taken and cultured. The isolated organism shows pink, mucoid colonies on MacConkey agar. Biochemical tests are performed, and the organism is found to be urease-positive, indole-negative, and citrate-positive. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?

A microbiologist observes samples of bacteria and notes that the bacteria exhibit motility at 22°C but become non-motile at 37 °C. Additionally, the bacteria is better isolated when kept at 4°C, and weekly subcultures are done. Which of the following organisms is least likely to be in the sample?
questions.explanation:
Organism

Differential Motility (22°C vs 37°C)

Cold Enrichment Isolation

Yersinia enterocolitica (Option A)

Motile at 22°C, Non-motile at 37°C

Yes

Yersinia pseudotuberculosis (Option B)

Motile at 22°C, Non-motile at 37°C

Yes

Listeria monocytogens (Option C)

Motile at 22°C, Non-motile at 37°C

Yes

Yersinia pestis

Non-motile

No

questions.text: Which statement is correct regarding the currently available vaccines for typhoid fever?

options.label: A
options.text: The Vi-CPS vaccine can be given to children under 2 years of age.

options.label: B
options.text: The Typhoral vaccine is given via intramuscular injection.

options.label: C
options.text: The Vi-rEPA vaccine can be administered to children under 2 years of age.

options.label: D
options.text: The Typhoral vaccine requires only a single dose for effective protection.

questions.correct_answer: C. The Vi-rEPA vaccine can be administered to children under 2 years of age.
questions.explanation:
Vaccine

Vi-CPS Vaccine

Typhoral Vaccine

Parenteral TAB Vaccine

Type

Vi antigen capsular polysaccharide

Oral live attenuated S. Typhi Ty21a

Heat-killed whole cell S. Typhi/S. Paratyphi A and B

Composition

Purified Vi capsular polysaccharide antigen from S. Typhi strain Ty2

Stable live attenuated mutant of S. Typhi strain Ty21a

Whole cell of S. Typhi and S. Paratyphi A and B, killed by heating at 50-60°C and preserved in 0.5% phenol.

Dosage

Single dose containing 25 μg of Vi antigen

4 doses taken orally on days 1, 3, 5, and 7

Two doses of 0.5 ml subcutaneously at an interval of 4-6 weeks; alternatively, 0.1 ml intradermally

Administration Route

Intramuscular (IM) or subcutaneous

Oral (enteric-coated capsules) (Option B)

Subcutaneous or intradermal

Age Indication

Only after 2 years of age (Option A)

Only after 6 years of age

Recommended for troops, medical and paramedical personnel in non-endemic areas; for all children in endemic areas

Booster

Every 2 years

Every 5 years with a full 4-dose series (Option D)

Not applicable

Duration of Protection

2 years

4 years

3 years

Mechanism of Action

Induces immune response to Vi antigen

Multiplies and initiates immune response but self-destructs

Induces immune response to whole bacterial cells

Special Considerations

Poorly immunogenic to children under 2 years

No antibiotics should be given during the vaccination period

Significant side effects led to discontinuation

Current Status

In use

In use

No longer in use due to side effects

questions.text: In the context of interpreting the Widal test results for typhoid fever, which of the following statements is not accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: The presence of high titers of O-antibodies generally indicates a later stage of infection.

options.label: B
options.text: A significant rise in H-antibody titers between acute and convalescent phases can confirm a diagnosis of typhoid fever.

options.label: C
options.text: The Widal test is most accurate when conducted within the first week of illness

options.label: D
options.text: False-positive results in the Widal test can occur due to prior vaccination or exposure to non-typhoidal Salmonella strains.

questions.correct_answer: C. The Widal test is most accurate when conducted within the first week of illness
questions.explanation:
Interpretation of WIDAL Test
 

TO

TH

AH

BH

S. Typhi

+

+

-

-

S. Paratyphi A

+

-

+

-

S. Paratyphi B

+

-

-

+

Early infection

+

-

-

-

Late infection

-

+

-

-

Vaccine

-

+

+

+

Where, TO : O Antigen, TH : S.Typhi H Antigen, AH : S.Paratyphi AH Antigen, BH : S. Paratyphi B H Antigen.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 10-day history of high fever, headache, and abdominal discomfort. He reports feeling increasingly fatigued and has developed a dry cough. On physical examination, his temperature is 39.5°C (103.1°F), his pulse is 60 beats/min, and he has rose-colored spots on his abdomen. Considering the timing of his symptoms, which diagnostic method is most appropriate for confirming the diagnosis at this stage?
questions.explanation:
Week 1(B)

Blood culture (Option A ruled out)

Week 2(A)

Antibody test (WIDAL) (Option B)

Week 3(S)

Stool culture (Option C ruled out)

Week 4(U)

Urine culture (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: A patient who is working as a cook in a restaurant had symptoms such as prolonged fever, abdominal pain, and diarrhea 8 months ago, was diagnosed with typhoid fever and has been asymptomatic since then. Several customers who dined at the restaurant recently developed similar symptoms. The cook in this scenario is an example of a:

A 25-year-old male presents with a 7-day history of high-grade fever, chills, and generalized weakness. The fever has been persistent and gradually increasing in intensity, reaching 39.5°C (103.1°F) and, often rising in the afternoon and evening. The patient also reports abdominal pain and has experienced several episodes of diarrhea, characterized by intermittent loose, greenish stools which started a few days after the onset of fever. On examination, pulse is 60/min, and BP is 110/70 mmHg. He appears ill with a coated tongue and mild hepatosplenomegaly. Based on the clinical scenario above, what is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
Given the various types of antigenic variations associated with Salmonella, which of the following statements is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Phase variation involves flagellar antigens in which Phase 1 antigens are species-specific and Phase 2 antigens are non-specific and widely shared among different species.

options.label: B
options.text: V-W variation refers to the presence of a surface layer of Vi antigen that masks the O antigen, which can be lost after multiple subcultures.

options.label: C
options.text: H-0 variation is associated with the permanent loss of flagella when salmonellae are grown on agar containing phenol.

options.label: D
options.text: S-R variation is associated with a change in colony morphology and the loss of the O antigen and virulence.

questions.correct_answer: C. H-0 variation is associated with the permanent loss of flagella when salmonellae are grown on agar containing phenol.
questions.explanation:
Antigenic Variation

Description

Mechanism

H-0 Variation

Loss of flagella

Phenotypic and temporary change when grown on agar containing phenol.

Phase Variation

Alternation between two sets of flagellar antigens (Phase 1 and Phase 2)

Involves two sets of genes in the bacterial genome. Phase 1 antigens are species-specific or shared by a few species, while Phase 2 antigens are more widely shared. (Option A)

V-W Variation

Presence of Vi antigen (V form) and loss of Vi antigen (W form)

Fresh isolates carry Vi antigen masking the O antigen (V form). Vi antigen is lost after several subcultures, exposing the O antigen (W form). (Option B)

S-R Variation

Change from smooth (S) to rough (R) colonies

Loss of O antigen and virulence, often through mutation. (Option D)

questions.text: Which of the following statements about prophylaxis against Yersinia pestis is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Sokhey's Modification of Haffkine Vaccine is a formalin-killed vaccine administered subcutaneously.

options.label: B
options.text: Chemoprophylaxis of Yersinia involves administration of Cotrimoxazole or Tetracycline orally for at least five days.

options.label: C
options.text: Sokhey's Modification of Haffkine Vaccine provides protection against all clinical types of plague.

options.label: D
options.text: The killed vaccine provides protection for up to 6 months.

questions.correct_answer: C. Sokhey's Modification of Haffkine Vaccine provides protection against all clinical types of plague.
questions.explanation:
Vaccine

Notes

Sokhey's Modification of Haffkine Vaccine

Formalin-killed vaccine, administered subcutaneously. Protects against bubonic plague. Provides protection for up to 6 months. (Option A and D)

Live vaccine

No longer recommended

Chemoprophylaxis

Cotrimoxazole/Tetracycline for 5 days (Option B)

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the clinic with a high fever, chills, and painful lymphadenopathy in the inguinal region. He mentions recent travel to a rural area known for plague outbreaks. Suspecting Yersinia pestis, the physician orders various diagnostic tests, including biochemical reactions and serology. Which of the following findings would support the diagnosis of Yersinia pestis?

options.label: A
options.text: Positive catalase test, Positive oxidase test, and Passive hemagglutination against F1 antigen with a titer> 64 A in a single sample

options.label: B
options.text: Negative catalase test, Positive oxidase test, Passive hemagglutination against F1 antigen with a titer> 64 A in a single sample

options.label: C
options.text: Positive catalase test, Negative oxidase test, and Passive hemagglutination against F1 antigen with a titer> 128 A in a single sample

options.label: D
options.text: Negative catalase test, Negative oxidase test, and Passive hemagglutination against F1 antigen with a titer> 128 A in a single sample

questions.correct_answer: C. Positive catalase test, Negative oxidase test, and Passive hemagglutination against F1 antigen with a titer> 128 A in a single sample
questions.explanation:
Biochemical Reactions

  • Fermentation [+ve acid production -ve gas production] - Glucose, Maltose, Mannitol
  • Catalase Test - Positive
  • Oxidase Test - Negative
  • IMViC - + - -

Serology
  • Passive hemagglutination by antibody against F1 antigen
  • Titre > 128 Å in a single sample (1:128)

questions.text: A 29-year-old man presents to the emergency department with high fever, chills, and a painful swelling in his axillary region. He reports that he recently returned from a trip to Himachal Pradesh. On physical examination, a large, tender lymph node is noted in the axillary region. Aspirate when stained with methylene blue is shown in the image below. Which of the following organisms does not show a similar typical appearance as seen in the image?
questions.explanation:
Plague (Yersinia pestis)

Endemic Foci
  • Kolar (Tamil Nadu),
  • Beed Latur (Maharashtra)
  • Rhoru (Himachal)

Reservoir

Wild rodents

Vector

Rat flea (Xenopsylla cheopis, Xenopsylla astia)

Types of Plague
  • Bubonic Plague: 2-7 days incubation period; Lymph node painful enlargement and fever
  • Pneumonic Plague: 1-3 days incubation period; Respiratory symptoms; Associated with bio-terrorism
  • Septicemic Plague: 2-7 days incubation period; A/k/a Black death; DIC, shock and multi-organ failure

Microscopic Findings

Safety pin appearance (Bipolar staining) using Wayson stain, Wright stain, Giemsa stain

Culture
  • Nutrient broth with oil/ghee (Ghee broth): Stalactite growth (hanging from the top)
  • Selective CIN agar: Bullseye colonies

 

Biochemical Reactions
  • Fermentation [+ve acid production -ve gas production]
  • Catalase positive
  • Oxidase negative
  • IMViC = - - + -

Vaccine

  • Recombinant R1F1v Vaccine: Pre-exposure Prophylaxis
  • Sokhey's Modification of Haffkine Vaccine- Protects only against bubonic plague,

Treatment

  • Streptomycin
  • Fluoroquinolones: For CNS and cardiovascular involvement

questions.text: Match the following Klebsiella species with the diseases they commonly cause: 1. Klebsiella pneumoniae A. Granuloma inguinale 2. Klebsiella oxytoca B. Pneumonia 3. Klebsiella granulomatis C. Rhinoscleroma 4. Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis D. Hemorrhagic colitis
questions.explanation:
Klebsiella Species

Disease Caused

Symptoms

Klebsiella pneumoniae

Pneumonia

Productive cough with "currant jelly" sputum, fever, chills, chest pain, difficulty breathing

 

Klebsiella oxytoca

Hemorrhagic colitis

Bloody diarrhea, abdominal pain and cramping, nausea, vomiting

Klebsiella granulomatis

Granuloma inguinale

Painless, beefy-red genital or anal ulcers, tissue granulation, bleeding from lesions

Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis

Rhinoscleroma

Nasal congestion, nasal discharge, nasal obstruction, crusting, swelling, tissue thickening, deformity

questions.text: In a microbiological study, two different strains of Proteus are inoculated at separate points on the same agar plate containing a non-inhibitory medium. Upon observation, the areas of growth from each strain remain distinctly separate with a line of demarcation between them. What phenomenon is being demonstrated in this experiment?
Which of the following bacteria exhibits a characteristic pattern as shown below?
Which of the following statements is false?

options.label: A
options.text: All members of Tribe Proteeae test positive for the phenylalanine deaminase (PPA) test

options.label: B
options.text: Morganella tests positive for Urease test

options.label: C
options.text: Proteus lowers urine pH and contributes to the formation of bladder stones.

options.label: D
options.text: Providencia tests negative for Urease test

questions.correct_answer: C. Proteus lowers urine pH and contributes to the formation of bladder stones.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient, hospitalized for two weeks following a motor vehicle accident, presents with fever, chills, and difficulty breathing. He has a central venous catheter in place. Blood cultures grow a gram-negative, facultative anaerobic bacillus that produces a red pigment on nutrient agar. Which of the following is NOT a feature of this organism?

options.label: A
options.text: Organisms commonly found in healthcare facilities

options.label: B
options.text: Respiratory infection characterized by bloody sputum

options.label: C
options.text: Cause keratitis in contact lens wearers

options.label: D
options.text: Prodigiosin is a red pigment seen in culture

questions.correct_answer: B. Respiratory infection characterized by bloody sputum

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with a urinary tract infection. A urine sample is cultured on MacConkey agar. The colonies appear pink and mucoid. A string test is performed, and the colonies form a viscous string longer than 5 mm. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
Which of the following infections is not typically caused by the recent- hyperviscous, hypervirulent strain of Klebsiella pneumoniae?

A 35-year-old male presents with painless, progressive genital ulcers. A tissue biopsy is taken, and a Wright-Giemsa stain is performed. The microscopic examination reveals Donovan bodies within macrophages as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
